[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Function: get_transaction()] [Deserialization Attack - High] Can malicious transaction data exploit vulnerabilities in encode::deserialize to cause crashes or memory corruption?

[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Function: get_transaction()] [Hex Decoding Validation - Medium] Can FromHex::from_hex be exploited with specially crafted hex strings to cause buffer issues?

[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Function: get_transaction()] [Transaction Witness Data - Medium] Does deserialization properly handle witness data for SegWit transactions, or can witness malleability affect txid calculations?

[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Error Type: RpcError] [Error Information Leakage - Low] Do error messages expose sensitive information about internal Bitcoin node state or configuration that could aid attackers?

[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Error Type: RpcError] [Error Code Exhaustiveness - Medium] Are all possible Bitcoin RPC error codes handled appropriately, or can unknown error codes cause panics or undefined behavior?

[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [RpcResponse Enum] [Untagged Deserialization - High] The #[serde(untagged)] attribute can cause ambiguous deserialization—can response structures be crafted to deserialize as Ok when they should be Err?

[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Error Struct] [Error Message Injection - Low] Can malicious error messages from the Bitcoin node contain escape sequences or formatting that breaks logging or monitoring systems?

[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Struct: Rpc] [Connection Pool Safety - Medium] Is the Client connection pool thread-safe and does it prevent request/response mixing under concurrent access?
[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Struct: Rpc] [Clone Safety - Medium] The Rpc struct derives Clone—can cloning cause issues with connection state or authentication credentials?

[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Multiple Functions] [Race Condition - High] If multiple validators call get_latest_block_number() -> get_block_hash() -> get_block() in sequence during a reorg, can they end up with inconsistent views of the chain state?

[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Overall Design] [Finality Assumption - Critical] Does this RPC client enforce CONFIRMATIONS depth before returning blocks as finalized, or must all callers implement this check separately?

[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Overall Design] [Block Scanning - Critical] If the processor scans blocks using these RPC calls, can block reorganizations cause duplicate processing of deposits or missed withdrawals?

[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Overall Design] [Batch Ordering - High] When processing multiple blocks, can inconsistent RPC responses cause batch ordering violations that break Serai's sequential processing requirement?

[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Overall Design] [Node Trust Model - Critical] The implementation trusts the Bitcoin node responses after basic validation—what happens if a validator runs a compromised Bitcoin node?

[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Overall Design] [Network Partition - High] During Bitcoin network partitions, can validators see different blockchain tips leading to consensus failure in Serai?
[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Multiple Functions] [Hash Collision - Low] Are SHA-256 hash collisions considered in the hash validation logic, or is hash uniqueness assumed?

[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Function: get_block_hash()] [Canonical Encoding - Medium] Does the hash byte reversal maintain canonical encoding such that the same logical hash always produces the same byte representation?

[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Multiple Functions] [Deterministic Serialization - High] Are Bitcoin's consensus serialization rules strictly followed to ensure deterministic results across all validators?

[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Function: rpc_call()] [Response Size Attack - High] Can the Bitcoin node return multi-gigabyte responses for getblock or getrawtransaction causing memory exhaustion?
[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Function: new()] [Connection Exhaustion - Medium] Can rapidly creating new Rpc instances exhaust connection pools or file descriptors?
[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Function: get_block()] [CPU Exhaustion - Medium] Can deserializing extremely complex blocks (e.g., with maximum witness data) cause CPU starvation?

[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Multiple Functions] [Network DoS - Medium] Can an attacker cause the Bitcoin node to become unresponsive, blocking all Serai operations that depend on these RPC calls?
[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Overall] [SegWit Handling - High] Are SegWit transaction formats including nested SegWit properly handled in serialization and txid calculation?
[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Overall] [Taproot Support - Medium] Does the deserialization properly support Taproot (P2TR) transactions and scripts introduced in Bitcoin Core 22.0?
[File: serai/networks/bitcoin/src/rpc.rs] [Overall] [Version Compatibility - Medium] Can Bitcoin Core version differences cause incompatible RPC responses or method signatures?
